docs.text: What's this? ¶ TietzeIO.CyShell is a Powershell module for interacting with the Cylance REST API written in C#. Core scenarios ¶ Core usage scenarios for this module are: Automation of common administrative tasks, e.g. mass operations or migrations To serve as a sample application for the TietzeIO.CyAPI set of libraries Why use it? ¶ What sets it apart from other modules (e.g. CyCLI 1 ) the most is: Performance - multiple threads, connection pools etc. Reliability - resilient access to backend APIs Type safety - no more dealing with dynamic objects Ease of use - as a result Please update! CyShell is the successor module to CyCLI, and you are encouraged to move your code to CyShell. If you are interested in CyCLI, you can find it here 1 CyCLI and CyShell have the same origin and author - CyShell is meant as CyCLI's successor and to be better in every aspect. ↩ ↩

docs.text: Connect-Cylance ¶ SYNOPSIS ¶ Connects to the specified console SYNTAX ¶ Connect - Cylance [ - Scope < String > ] [ - ProtectCache ] [ - OpticsCache ] [ - ProxyServer < String > ] [[ - Console ] < String > ] [ < CommonParameters > ] DESCRIPTION ¶ Connects to the Cylance console specified and establish an authenticated session using the specified console configuration profile. Console configuration profiles hold the API credentials. They can be created and removed using New-CylanceConsole and Remove-CylanceConsole . It can also initialize caches as you connect. EXAMPLES ¶ Example 1 ¶ PS C : \> Connect-Cylance MyTenant -ProtectCache -OpticsCache This will connect to the Console named "MyTenant" in your consoles file (typically consoles.json, but different implementations of configuration storage are available; you can create consoles using the New-CylanceConsole command), and populate the Protect (e.g. device, policy, zone data) and Optics (detections, detection rules) caches that can be used later to e.g. refer to policies by name, and use tab auto-completion for certain fields when used interactively. PARAMETERS ¶ -Console ¶ The console record in the console definition file. Type : String Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Accepted values : <console profile name, use tab key for autocompletion> Required : False Position : 1 Default value : None Accept pipeline input : False Accept wildcard characters : False -OpticsCache ¶ Populates the OPTICS cache. Type : SwitchParameter Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Required : False Position : Named Default value : None Accept pipeline input : False Accept wildcard characters : False -ProtectCache ¶ Populates the PROTECT cache. Type : SwitchParameter Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Required : False Position : Named Default value : None Accept pipeline input : False Accept wildcard characters : False -ProxyServer ¶ Proxy server to use, if any Type : String Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Required : False Position : Named Default value : None Accept pipeline input : False Accept wildcard characters : False -Scope ¶ By default, connections are global. This is best for interactive sessions. If you wish to connect to multiple consoles in parallel, you should use -Scope None and then supply the API handle returned to every cmdlet explicitly. Type : String Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Accepted values : Session, None Required : False Position : Named Default value : None Accept pipeline input : False Accept wildcard characters : False CommonParameters ¶ This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters . INPUTS ¶ None ¶ OUTPUTS ¶ TietzeIO.CyShell.Session.ApiConnectionHandle ¶ NOTES ¶ RELATED LINKS ¶

docs.text: Convert-CylanceObjectToJson ¶ SYNOPSIS ¶ Dumps an object to the same JSON form that would be sent to the console by the REST transaction. SYNTAX ¶ Convert - CylanceObjectToJson - Object < ICyEntity > [ < CommonParameters > ] DESCRIPTION ¶ This cmdlet is used to serialize an object to JSON using the same serialization options used by the CyShell module; this is typically what would be sent over the wire if you were to PUT or POST such an object. EXAMPLES ¶ Example 1 ¶ PS C : \> Get-CylancePolicies | Get-CylancePolicy | Convert-CylanceObjectToJson Returns the exact JSON representation for all policies in the tenant. PARAMETERS ¶ -Object ¶ The object to dump to a JSON string. Type : ICyEntity Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Required : True Position : Named Default value : None Accept pipeline input : True (ByValue) Accept wildcard characters : False CommonParameters ¶ This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters . INPUTS ¶ TietzeIO.CyAPI.Entities.ICyEntity ¶ OUTPUTS ¶ TietzeIO.CyShell.Session.ApiConnectionHandle ¶ NOTES ¶ RELATED LINKS ¶

SYNTAX ¶ Enable - CylanceApplicationTemplate [ - Policy ] < CyPolicy > [ - Template ] < String [] > [ < CommonParameters > ] DESCRIPTION ¶ {{Applies script control, memory protection, and file scan exclusions from an application template. docs.text: Get-CylanceDevices ¶ c SYNOPSIS ¶ Returns a list of all registered devices. SYNTAX ¶ Get - CylanceDevices [ - Api < ApiConnectionHandle > ] [ - Zone < CyZone > ] [ < CommonParameters > ] DESCRIPTION ¶ Returns a list of all registered devices in the Cylance console. Example Properties are shown below EXAMPLES ¶ Example 1 ¶ PS C : \> Get-CylanceDevices date_first_registered : 7 / 16 / 2019 4 : 36 : 03 PM policy : Sample Policy ( 123344558 - 7544 - 1337-ab013 - 3322432423437378 ) state : Offline agent_version : 2 . 0 . 1534 ip_addresses : { 10 . 10 . 10 . 20 , 192 . 168 . 1 . 100 } mac_addresses : { 00 - 0C - 29-E2-F8-DD , 00 - 0C - 29-E2-F8-E7 } device_id : 234f3abf2-c5d4 - 3347 - 1337-b4931a7df7ec device_name : Malware-Laptop A list of the above item will be returned. Example 2 ¶ Getting device details from a list of devices PS C : \> Get-CylanceDevices | where device_name -like "Malware*" | Get-CylanceDevice host_name : Malware-Laptop os_version : Microsoft Windows 7 Professional , Service Pack 1 last_logged_in_user : Malware-Laptop \ Demo distinguished_name : update_type : update_available : False background_detection : False is_safe : True date_last_modified : date_offline : Zones : date_first_registered : 11 / 26 / 2018 5 : 09 : 16 PM policy : Sample Policy ( 123344558 - 7544 - 1337-ab013 - 3322432423437378 ) state : Online agent_version : 2 . 0 . 1534 ip_addresses : { 10 . 10 . 10 . 20 , 192 . 168 . 1 . 100 } mac_addresses : { 00 - 0C - 29-E2-F8-DD , 00 - 0C - 29-E2-F8-E7 } device_id : 234f3abf2-c5d4 - 3347 - 1337-b4931a7df7ec device_name : Malware-Laptop PARAMETERS ¶ -Api ¶ An API session handle (global session handle will be used if none exists in the current session). Type : ApiConnectionHandle Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Required : False Position : Named Default value : None Accept pipeline input : False Accept wildcard characters : False -Zone ¶ {{ Fill Zone Description }} Type : CyZone Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Required : False Position : Named Default value : None Accept pipeline input : False Accept wildcard characters : False CommonParameters ¶ This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters . INPUTS ¶ None ¶ OUTPUTS ¶ TietzeIO.CyAPI.Entities.CyDeviceBase ¶ NOTES ¶ RELATED LINKS ¶

docs.text: Set-CylancePolicyForDevice ¶ SYNOPSIS ¶ Assigns policy to a device. SYNTAX ¶ Set - CylancePolicyForDevice - Device < CyDeviceBase > [ - Policy < CyPolicyMinimalMetaData > ] [ - Api < ApiConnectionHandle > ] [ < CommonParameters > ] DESCRIPTION ¶ Will apply an existing policy to a device. EXAMPLES ¶ Example 1 ¶ PS C : \> $device = ( Get-CylanceDevices )[ 0 ] PS C : \> $policy = ( Get-CylancePolicies )[ 1 ] PS C : \> $device | Set-CylancePolicyForDevice -Policy $policy Takes the first device in a tenant, and applies the second policy in the list to it (basically a randomly chosen policy, because order is not guaranteed). PARAMETERS ¶ -Api ¶ An API session handle (global session handle will be used if none exists in the current session). Type : ApiConnectionHandle Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Required : False Position : Named Default value : None Accept pipeline input : False Accept wildcard characters : False -Device ¶ {{ Fill Device Description }} Type : CyDeviceBase Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Required : True Position : Named Default value : None Accept pipeline input : True (ByValue) Accept wildcard characters : False -Policy ¶ {{ Fill Policy Description }} Type : CyPolicyMinimalMetaData Parameter Sets : (All) Aliases : Required : False Position : Named Default value : None Accept pipeline input : False Accept wildcard characters : False CommonParameters ¶ This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters . INPUTS ¶ TietzeIO.CyAPI.Entities.CyDeviceBase ¶ OUTPUTS ¶ TietzeIO.CyAPI.Entities.CyDeviceMetaData ¶ NOTES ¶ RELATED LINKS ¶

docs.text: TietzeIO.CyShell Module ¶ Description ¶ A PowerShell module for fast, easy, and reliable interaction with the Cylance REST API services. TietzeIO.CyShell Cmdlets ¶ Backup-CylanceOpticsPackages ¶ Creates a backup of OPTICS packages to local ZIP files Backup-CylanceTenant ¶ Creates a backup of settings in a tenant Invoke-CylanceIssuerSignatureMissingWizard ¶ Tests for OPTICS detection instances that are likely caused by a local configuration issue in the tenant environment (outside the Cylance configuration) preventing Windows from performing proper certificate validation checks Add-CylanceDeviceToZone ¶ Adds a device to a zone Add-ToCylanceGlobalQuarantineList ¶ Adds a file hash to the Global Quarantine list Add-ToCylanceGlobalSafeList ¶ Adds a file hash to the Global Safelist Block-CylanceDeviceThreat ¶ Blocks (quarantines) a file-based threat on a device Clear-CylanceCache ¶ Clears the session cache for the current session Connect-Cylance ¶ Connects to the Cylance API for a console Convert-CylanceObjectToJson ¶ Converts an object used by the module into the JSON representation typically sent to the REST backend (used mostly for troubleshooting purposes by module contributors) Convert-CylanceTDRtoXLSX ¶ Converts a Cylance Threat Data Report to XLSX Copy-CylancePolicy ¶ Creates a duplicate (clone) of a Cylance device policy Disconnect-Cylance ¶ Disconnects an API session Enable-CylanceApplicationTemplate ¶ Adds and enables an application template to a device policy Get-CylanceArtifact ¶ Retrieves an artifact from a detection event Get-CylanceCachedDetections ¶ Dumps cached detections from the current session Get-CylanceCachedThreatDevices ¶ Retrieves cached threat instances Get-CylanceCachedThreats ¶ Retrieves cached threats Get-CylanceConsole ¶ Retrieves API/console configuration entries Get-CylanceDetection ¶ Retrieves a detection with details Get-CylanceDetectionException ¶ Retrieves a detection exception definition Get-CylanceDetectionExceptions ¶ Retrieves metadata for all detection exceptions Get-CylanceDetectionRule ¶ Retrieves a detection rule with details Get-CylanceDetectionRules ¶ Retrieves metadata for all detection rules Get-CylanceDetectionRuleSet ¶ Retrieves a detection rule set with details Get-CylanceDetectionRuleSets ¶ Retrieves metadata for all detection rulesets Get-CylanceDetections ¶ Retrieves metadata for the 10000 most recent detections Get-CylanceDevice ¶ Retrieves details for a device Get-CylanceDevices ¶ Retrieves metadata for all devices Get-CylanceDeviceThreats ¶ Retrieves all threat instances for a device Get-CylanceGlobalQuarantineList ¶ Retrieves the Global Quarantine list Get-CylanceGlobalSafeList ¶ Retrieves the Global Safelist Get-CylanceInstaQueries ¶ Retrieves metadata for all InstaQueries Get-CylanceInstaQuery ¶ Retrieves all data for a particular InstaQuery Get-CylanceLockdownHistory ¶ Retrieves the lockdown history and certain metadata items for a device Get-CylancePolicies ¶ Retrievs metadata for all device policies Get-CylancePolicy ¶ Retrieves a device policy Get-CylanceSession ¶ Returns the current API session Get-CylanceTDR ¶ Downloads a Threat Data Report Get-CylanceThreat ¶ Retrieves threat details for a file-based threat Get-CylanceThreatDevices ¶ Retrieves device instance details for a particular threat Get-CylanceThreats ¶ Retrieves metadata for all file-based threats Get-CylanceUser ¶ Retrieves a user object Get-CylanceUsers ¶ Retrieves metadata for all user objects Get-CylanceVersion ¶ Returns version information for this module Get-CylanceZone ¶ Retrieves details for a zone Get-CylanceZones ¶ Retrieves metadata for all zones Hide-CylanceInstaQuery ¶ Removes an InstaQuery from view in the console Invoke-CylanceArtifactAnalysis ¶ Performs an analysis of cached detection details and mines for commonality in artifacts, allowing easy identification of candidates for the creation of detection exclusions Invoke-CylanceDetectionRuleAnalysis ¶ TODO OUTDATED Performs frequency analysis of detections by detection rule. Invoke-CylanceDetectionStats ¶ Performs frequency analysis of detections by detection rule. Invoke-CylanceThreatAnalysis ¶ Performs frequency analysis of cached threats by classification. Output can be used to quarantine/safelist Invoke-CylanceThreatPathAnalysis ¶ Performs frequency analysis of cached threats by path. Output can be used to quarantine/safelist New-CylanceConsole ¶ Creates a new console configuration entry in the configuration store New-CylanceDetectionException ¶ Creates a new detection exception rule New-CylanceDetectionRuleSet ¶ Creates a new detection rule set New-CylanceInstaQuery ¶ Starts a new InstaQuery New-CylancePolicy ¶ Creates a new device policy New-CylanceUser ¶ Creates a new console user New-CylanceZone ¶ Creates a new zone for devices Open-CylanceDetection ¶ Opens a browser with the details view for a particular detection Remove-CylanceConsole ¶ Removes a console configuration entry from the configuration store Remove-CylanceDetection ¶ Removes a detection Remove-CylanceDevice ¶ Removes a device Remove-CylanceDeviceFromZone ¶ Removes a device from a zone Remove-CylancePolicy ¶ Removes a policy Remove-CylanceZone ¶ Removes a zone Remove-FromCylanceGlobalQuarantineList ¶ Removes a file hash from the Global Quarantine List Remove-FromCylanceGlobalSafeList ¶ Removes a file hash from the Global Safelist Select-CylanceArtifact ¶ Fill in the Description Select-CylanceDetection ¶ Fill in the Description Select-CylanceThreat ¶ Fill in the Description Select-CylanceThreatDevices ¶ Fill in the Description Set-CylanceConsole ¶ Fill in the Description Set-CylancePolicyForDevice ¶ Fill in the Description Set-CylanceSession ¶ Fill in the Description Sync-CylanceCache ¶ Fill in the Description Unblock-CylanceDeviceThreat ¶ Fill in the Description Update-CylanceDetection ¶ Fill in the Description Update-CylanceDetectionException ¶ Fill in the Description Update-CylancePolicy ¶ Fill in the Description Update-CylanceZone ¶ Fill in the Description

docs.text: Safelisting and quarantining ¶ Add all hashes from an Excel file to Global Quarantine list ¶ import-excel .\ HashesFromExcel . xlsx ). Hash | Add-ToCylanceGlobalSafeList -Category None -Reason "Test" Prerequisite Note that this example assumes that you have the module ImportExcel installed already. Safelist all 'Trusted' files ¶ Get-CylanceThreats | where classification -eq "Trusted" | Add-ToCylanceGlobalSafeList -Category None -Reason "Trusted" What happens when a file was safelisted already? This script does not care; and CyShell will silently ignore those entries. Device management ¶ List devices that have been offline ¶ To list the devices that have been offline for longer than $days : $days = 5 get-cylancedevices | get-cylancedevice | where date_offline -ne $null | where date_offline -lt ( Get-Date ). AddDays (- $days ) Info The Get-CylanceDevice cmdlet expands the metadata object returned by the Get-CylanceDevices cmdlet into a full device object that includes the date_offline (date the device went offline) date. You need to test for $null because devices that are currently online, and some other devices, may not have the field populated at all; you want to exclude those from comparison. Policy management ¶ Get all script exclusions from all policies ¶ ( Get-CylancePolicies | Get-CylancePolicy ). ScriptExclusions | Sort -Unique Info The Get-CylancePolicy cmdlet expands the metadata object returned by the Get-CyancePolicies cmdlet into a full policy object. Policy objects do not just contain the policy data, but are extended with convenience methods and properties that give access to policy logic without having to understand the policy object itself; one of those methods is .ScriptExclusions , which returns a list of script control rules set in the policy. When applied to a set of objects in Powershell ( (...) ), it will be called on each object in the set (= on each policy in the list). The resultant rule entries may contain duplicates, which are removed and sorted using | Sort -Unique . Get all memory protection exclusions from all policies ¶ ( Get-CylancePolicies | Get-CylancePolicy ). MemoryExclusions | Sort -Unique Info See note above for details . Copy memory protection and script control exclusions to all policies ¶ This will collect script control and memory protection exclusion settings and add all of them to all policies that have Script Control or Memory Protection enabled $policies = Get-CylancePolicies | Get-CylancePolicy $s_ex = $policies . ScriptExclusions | sort -Unique $m_ex = $policies . MemoryExclusions | sort -Unique foreach ( $policy in $policies ) { if ( $policy . ScriptControlEnabled ) { foreach ( $s in $s_ex ) { $policy . AddScriptExclusion ( $s ) } } if ( $policy . MemoryProtectionEnabled ) { foreach ( $m in $m_ex ) { $policy . AddMemoryExclusion ( $m ) } } } $policies | Update-CylancePolicy Info If an entry is already present, the convenient update methods AddScriptExclusion and AddMemoryExclusion will just ignore the entry. It will not be added twice. Warning This requires CyShell 1.0.8 at a minimum Warning This sample code will write all policies, not just those that were updated Create a new policy ¶ This creates a new policy NEW POLICY in the current session: $policy = New-CylancePolicy -Name "NEW POLICY" Info The returned object is of type CyPolicy and allows you to access the raw structure of the policy as well as convenient methods and properties to manipulate the policy. Warning It is strongly advised to always use the convenience methods (available at the top level of the policy) rather than accessing policy properties directly. Policy manipulation using the raw policy properties is difficult and requires knowledge that is not commonly available. The convenience methods can be found in the CyPolicy documentation of the TietzeIO.CyAPI library. Working with detections ¶ Mine detections ¶ This examines all detections for commonalities: Connect-Cylance -Console MyConsole -ProtectCache -OpticsCache $Analysis = Invoke-CylanceArtifactAnalysis This examines the most recent 10,000 detections and analyzes them for artifact/facet commonalities by organizing collected combinations of artifacts/facets from a detectin in buckets built from a subset of the facets (e.g. one bucket could be "target process image file hash" and "target process commandline", while another bucket could be "instigating process name" and "destination network address"). You can examine the buckets by looking at the output: $Analysis | ft To look at a result, pick one rule, and look at the buckets and the number of hits for each bucket. These are candidates for bulk handling, or for creating detection exclusions: $Analysis [ 0 ]. Buckets | select type , name , hits | ft Let's say you found out that anything in the top-most bucket (highest number of hits) you'd like to handle by updating the detection status for all affected detections: $Analysis [ 0 ]. Buckets [ 0 ]. Members . Detection | Update-CylanceDetection -Status Reviewed -Comment "Done" Update detections based on artifacts ¶ Select all detections (from the cached detections) where the Instigating Process artifact matches *cmd*/c sc query* and update the detections. Connect-Cylance -Console MyConsole -OpticsCache $matching_detections = Get-CylanceCachedDetections -Detailed | ForEach -Object { $process = $_ | Select-CylanceArtifact -Type Process -Source 'Instigating Process' ; if ( $process . CommandLine -ilike "*cmd*/c sc query*" ) { $_ } } $matching_detections | Update-CylanceDetection -Status Reviewed -Comment "This detection is not relevant"

docs.text: Concepts ¶ Configuration storage ¶ Configuration storage enables easy automation and convenient access by making connecting to a backend API easy. Console configuration profiles are persisted in a .JSON file and can be used to refer to a configuration profile by name, eliminating the need to store credentials in your scripts. There are two different providers available that store configuration locally between sessions: The DPAPI Configuration Storage Adapter : This is platform-specific for Windows, and automatically enabled for persisting configuration entries when you install in Windows. The Plaintext Configuration Storage Adapter : This is platform-agnostic and supports Windows, MacOS, Linux, and is automatically enabled for persisting configuration entries when you install on non-Windows platforms. Adapter Supported OS Capabilities DPAPI Windows Encrypted secret storage using Windows DPAPI in a JSON file; secrets can only be accessed by the same user Plaintext Any (Windows, MacOS, Linux) Plaintext secret storage in a JSON file Info The JSON file is stored in the user's platform-specific profile directory. On Windows, that would be %USERPROFILE%\.cyapi , on Linux, $HOME\.cyapi . For legacy migration reasons from CyCLI to CyShell, if a consoles.json and/or consoles-plaintext.json exists already in %USERPROFILE% , it will be used instead. Type safe objects ¶ All object types retrieved from the API are converted to .NET objects. This means that individual cmdlets do not operate on a generic PSObject type object, but expect that inputs are the relevant type. Warning In CyCLI it was relatively easy to make mistakes - e.g. novice users would expect that for a -Device argument, they could just supply a device name instead of a device object with a Guid in it. This was not possible, and the command would error out with unexpected side effects. In CyShell, arguments are type safe and you can only pass the right type to a cmdlet. This makes piping outputs from one cmdlet into another cmdlet much safer. Another effect of using objects is that some of the objects provide additional methods for convenient manipulation of objects; e.g. manipulating policy, because of its structure, is excessively difficult if you were to do it by hand.
docs.title: Foundations

docs.text: Configuration storage enables easy automation and convenient access by making connecting to a backend API easy. Console configuration profiles are persisted in a .JSON file and can be used to refer to a configuration profile by name, eliminating the need to store credentials in your scripts. There are two different providers available that store configuration locally between sessions: The DPAPI Configuration Storage Adapter : This is platform-specific for Windows, and automatically enabled for persisting configuration entries when you install in Windows. The Plaintext Configuration Storage Adapter : This is platform-agnostic and supports Windows, MacOS, Linux, and is automatically enabled for persisting configuration entries when you install on non-Windows platforms. Adapter Supported OS Capabilities DPAPI Windows Encrypted secret storage using Windows DPAPI in a JSON file; secrets can only be accessed by the same user Plaintext Any (Windows, MacOS, Linux) Plaintext secret storage in a JSON file Info The JSON file is stored in the user's platform-specific profile directory. On Windows, that would be %USERPROFILE%\.cyapi , on Linux, $HOME\.cyapi . For legacy migration reasons from CyCLI to CyShell, if a consoles.json and/or consoles-plaintext.json exists already in %USERPROFILE% , it will be used instead.

docs.text: Supported platforms ¶ CyShell supports Windows, MacOS, and Linux. On MacOS and Linux you will need to install PowerShell Core first. Installation ¶ To install, use the PowershellGallery distribution: Install-Module TietzeIO . CyShell PowerShellGet error If you receive this error message: WARNING: The specified module 'CyCLI' with PowerShellGetFormatVersion '2.0' is not supported by the current version of PowerShellGet. Get the latest version of the PowerShellGet module to install this module, 'CyCLI'. ...then you need to upgrade PowerShellGet to install. This is caused by a change in the minimum required PowerShellGet package version for PowerShellGallery.com. To fix it, from an administrative PowerShell prompt, enter Update-Module PowerShellGet -force , and after it completes successfully, restart the administrative PowerShell prompt and follow the instructions above again. Could not load file or assembly 'netstandard' If you receive an error message related to loading 'netstandard' on Windows , then most likely you are using an older .NET Framework version with Powershell. Update .NET Framework to 4.7.2 or higher and you should be good to go. This dependency is coded into the .psd1 module definition file, but for some reason PowerShellGet and Powershell both seem to ignore it... To use the module: Import-Module TietzeIO . CyShell Note CyShell uses console configuration profiles (stored in a JSON file) to manage API credentials for connecting to the Cylance console backend. This means you do not have to fiddle with API credentials in your code, and can just re-use them from a "console directory". Create your first console profile ¶ To create a first console profile MyConsole in Region euc1 with API ID 12345678 , API secret 12345678 and API tenant ID 12345678 (you can configure the actual values in your console under Settings > Integration ): New-CylanceConsole -Console MyConsole -Region euc1 -APIID 12345678 -APISecret 12345678 -APITenantId 12345678 You can the connect the console and e.g. retrieve all devices: Get-CylanceDevices Next steps ¶ Read through Foundations for a better understanding of how the module can be used. Access the Cmdlets Reference See examples, like useful One Liners
docs.title: Getting started

docs.text: New to Powershell? ¶ To help you get started with CyShell, you need to become somewhat comfortable with Powershell. You also need to have a functional understanding of scripting in Powershell or some other language or shell. Note If you are familiar with UNIX shells or an object oriented language, you can get proficient in Powershell very quickly. You may be able to save a lot of time by keeping some of the core concepts of Powershell in mind. Also, don't forget: Powershell is cross-platform, and so is CyShell - you can use it on Windows, Linux, and Mac easily. Powershell is pipeline-driven ¶ Just like the UNIX shells you may be familiar with, in Powershell you frequently operate on output streams coming from one command (called cmdlet in Powershell) that are passed to another cmdlet as input. E.g. a list of devices output by Get-CylanceDevices , piped into Powershell's own Where-Object general filtering cmdlet for filtering, whose output is then piped into Set-CylancePolicyForDevice as input objects describing the devices to assign policy for. Powershell is object based ¶ Instead of passing unstructured streams of strings (like you do in typical UNIX shells) you pass structured objects that have properties and methods. Powershell exposes .NET, so you have a vast library of operations at your disposal, and easy extensibility. In other words, you never substitute for structure by matching for e.g. character 3-12 of every line of input; instead, you'd match on $_ 's (the placeholder for the current object passed by a pipeline) properties, e.g. $_.device_name . Powershell has guessable parameters ¶ Rather than having to know command line switches, the meaning of single-letter command line arguments, and the available values, in many places cmdlets will support static or dynamic auto-completion of arguments using the <tab> key. You can just guess parameters By typing a dash - on the command line of a cmdlet and pressing the <tab> key, you can enumerate through all available parameter names. And once you have the parameter name, you can do the same for its possible values. Powershell has guessable cmdlets ¶ Cmdlets generally are formed as a combination of verb and noun, with a dash in between; e.g. Connect-Cylance . There are well-known verbs (CyShell uses these: Backup , Connect , Get , Add-To , Remove-From , Block , Unblock , Enable ...), followed by a noun. In case of CyShell, the noun always starts with Cylance . Powershell has built-in help ¶ If you want all cmdlets listed that satisfy a particular naming expression, try this one: Get-Help *-*Cylance* to get a list of all CyShell cmdlets.
docs.title: New to Powershell?
